title: Introduction to Economics
headline: Learn the fundamentals of economics in this free online certificate course.
description: This free online cert course teaches you the fundamentals of economics. It covers a wide range of topics such as GDP, the wealth of nations and economic growth, capital, accumulation and the economics of ideas. The course will be of great interest to anyone who wants to make a career out of business or economics or simply wants to learn more about how the financial side of the world works. So make sure you start your learning today.

courseDescription:
Macroeconomics refers to the study of an economy as a whole. If you’re interested in knowing more about how your national economy functions, this course is an excellent choice. The course begins by discussing gross domestic product (GDP), explaining what it is, nominal vs real GDP and the standard of living, as well as how GDP is analyzed through national spending.

The course then moves on to talk about the wealth of nations, looking at the basic facts of wealth and how growth rates are crucial. It also explores innovations and looks at both growth miracles and disasters, exploring what contributes to the former and what can cause the latter. The course also discusses the importance of institutions and geography and economic growth.

Finally, the course moves on to introduce you to the Solow Model and how it helps to distinguish cutting edge growth. It also teaches you about the economics of ideas, human capital and how the incentivization of ideas through patents, prizes and subsidies can help growth. This course is an excellent choice for those studying economics, teachers of economics, or anyone who is interested in macroeconomics.

Start Course Now

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, learn how to calculate gross domestic product.Then, learn about GDP per capita and how this formula can give insight into the habits and abilities of the population. Lastly, learn two approaches for analysing gross domestic product, the national spending approach, or the factor income approach.
topics: Real GDP Per Capita and the Standard of Living

modules.name: Module
modules.details: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
modules.description: In this module, learn about real GDP per capita. Once you understand real GDP per capita, you can begin to understand the wealth of nations and the disparities between them. Learn about innovationism, coastlines, the economic puzzle, and how these factors relate to economic growth.
topics: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth: Learning Outcomes
The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth: Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Growth, Capital, Accumulation, and the Economics of Ideas
modules.description: In this module, learn about the Solow Model, which states that economic growth is a result of physical capital, human capital, and ideas. Learn the difference between cutting-edge growth and catching-up growth, which type of growth comes as a result of ideas, and which grows at a faster rate. Finally, learn about incentivization of ideas through patents, prizes, and subsidies.
topics: Growth, Capital, Accumulation, and the Economics of Ideas: Learning Outcomes
The Solow Model and the Steady State
Office Hours: The Solow Model - Investments vs. Ideas
Growth, Capital, Accumulation, and the Economics of Ideas: Lesson Summary

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Upon completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Define gross domestic product.
    • Differentiate between nominal gross domestic product and real gross domestic product.
    • Explain how health, happiness, and education relate to real GDP per capita. 
    • Calculate GDP using either a national spending approach or a factor income approach. 
  • What is Gross Domestic Product (GDP)?

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Splitting GDP

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
  • The main points of this module are as follows:
    • GDP (gross domestic product) is the market value of all finished goods and services.
    • Nominal GDP is not adjusted for inflation and does not account for increases in population.
    • Real GDP is adjusted for inflation.
    • Real GDP per capita is positively correlated with life expectancy, happiness, and education.
    • When using a national spending approach to analyzing GDP, GDP is split into three categories: consumption goods bought by the public, investment goods bought by the public, and government purchases.
    • When using a factor income approach to analyzing GDP, GDP is the total sum of: employee compensation, rents, interest, and profit. When using this approach, GDP is referred to as GDI (or gross domestic income.)
    • Real GDP per capita measures an average citizen’s command over goods and services.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain innovation and how it occurs. 
    • Describe the pieces that make up the “economic puzzle”. 
    • Explain how growth rates explain wealth disparities between different countries.
  • Basic Facts of Wealth

  • Geography and Economic Growth

  • The Puzzle of Growth

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The Puzzle of Growth

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
  • The main points from this module are as follows:
    • Real GDP per capita is a country’s gross domestic product, divided by its population.
    • Since 1800 real GDP per capita in the U.S. has doubled roughly every 35 years.
    • The world exploded with innovationism after the 18th century. This was the result of: property rights, non-corrupt courses, rules of law, the rise of access to education, and reliable energy. 
    • Institutions guide a country’s choices – which paths to follow, which actions to take, which signals to listen to, and which ones to ignore. 
    • Coastlines are a major driver of economic growth. To trade in landlocked areas makes trade more expensive and makes it harder to spark economic growth. 
    • The “economic puzzle” is made up of productivity, incentives, institutions, country’s history, ideas, culture, geography, and luck.
    • Productivity is made up of physical capital, human capital, technological knowledge, and entrepreneurs. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain the purpose of the Solow model.
    • Explain the characteristics of cutting-edge growth and catching-up growth.
    • Explain how human capital, physical capital, and ideas contribute to growth.
    • Discuss the incentives of patents, prizes, and subsidies and which is the best incentivization method. 
    • Identify the idea equation.
  • Introduction to the Solow Model

  • The Economics of Ideas

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The Economics of Ideas

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Patents, Prizes, and Subsidies

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The Idea Equation

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The Idea Equation

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
  • The main points from this module are as follows:
    • The Solow model is a simple model which explains economic growth. 
    • The Solow model helps to differentiate between catching-up growth and cutting-edge growth. Countries grow much faster when they are “catching-up”. Cutting-edge growth occurs primarily because of increases in ideas.
    • In the Solow model, human capital is represented by eL, physical capital is represented by K, and ideas are represented by A.
    • Ideas are nonrivalrous.
    • A country is in a steady state when depreciation = investment. 
    • Physical capital and human capital only provide a temporary boost to economic growth. 
    • Patents give entrepreneurs a monopoly on their ideas.
    • If one country is poorer than another, but both have similar institutions, the poorer country will eventually catch up to the richer country, and at a faster pace.
    • Ideas foster growth at the cutting edge. 
  • Lesson Summary
  • The main points from this module are as follows:
    • The Solow model is a simple model which explains economic growth. 
    • The Solow model helps to differentiate between catching-up growth and cutting-edge growth. Countries grow much faster when they are “catching-up”. Cutting-edge growth occurs primarily because of increases in ideas.
    • In the Solow model, human capital is represented by eL, physical capital is represented by K, and ideas are represented by A.
    • Ideas are nonrivalrous.
    • A country is in a steady state when depreciation = investment. 
    • Physical capital and human capital only provide a temporary boost to economic growth. 
    • Patents give entrepreneurs a monopoly on their ideas.
    • If one country is poorer than another, but both have similar institutions, the poorer country will eventually catch up to the richer country, and at a faster pace.
    • Ideas foster growth at the cutting edge.
